document.text: sister Southern States, which had already seceded. The call went out for volunteers to defend the firesides of the Old Do minion. Appomattox County responded nobly. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. From 1870 to the present has been a period of rebuilding and achievement. From its creation the County has been served until now by the following Officers CIRCUIT JUDGESJudges G. A. Wingfield, J. D. Hors- rv, Sam Coleman, George J. Hundley, Robt. F. Hutcheson and Joel W. Flood. COUNTY JUDGESLewis Daniel Isbell, Henry T. Par-  rish and David A. Christian. TRIAL JUSTICEST. R. Horseley and L. F. Ferguson. COUNTY CLERKSJohn T. Bocock, Henry F. Bocock, Geo. T. Peers, Geo. W. Abbitt, John Rolfe Horsley and Claude W. Smith. , COMMONWEALTHS ATTORNEYSThos. S. Bocock, L. D. Isbell, Crawford Jones, Edward Woodson, T. J. Thornhill, David A. Christian, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson, Joel W. Flood and W. M. Abbitt. SHERIFFSJoel Watkins, Geo. T. Peers, William Paris, Wilson Hix, W. T. Johnson, Wm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, T. B. Bryant, S. P. Coleman, Frank W. McKinney and H. W. Mc Kinney. COMMISSIONERS OF THE REVENUEThos W. Johns, Isaac Adams, Andrew B. Baker, John W. Gilliam, Geo. W. Ab bitt, Van Gilliam, Wm. Statham, L. E. Smith, H. C. Babcock, E. R. Abbott and J. H. OBrien. COUNTY TREASURERSWm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, S. R. Franklin, D. Mott Robertson, R. F. Burke and R. L. Burke. SUPERINTENDENTS OF SCHOOLSC. H. Chilton, J. B. Bristow, J. K. Hannah, N. R. Featherston and J. A. Burke. STATE SENATORSThe County has furnished the fol lowing State SenatorsCol. Wyatt Elliott, Col. Samuel D. Mc Dearmon, Col. Robt. B. Poore, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson and Chas. T. Moses. HOUSE OF DELEGATESThe following citizens of the county have served in the House of Delegates Col, Samuel D. McDearmon, Zachariah Cheatham, Crawford Jones, R. P. Poore, Joel W. Flood, Thos. S. Bocock, James Watkins, D. Mott Robertson, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, J. W. Harwood, Ster ling C. Stratton, Willis H. Ligon, J. R. Horsley, J. C. Jones, A. B. Thornhill, T. J. Stratton, J. W. Cawthorn and R. L. Burke. The Constitution of 1902, abolished the County Court, the duties of which were transferred to the Circuit Court, the County Clerk and the Board of Supervisors.

document.text: First Sergeant Nathaniel Gray Jones and Mrs. Jones. She was two years old at the time of the Surrender in 1865. She is reanarkedly active and mentally alert, and relates in teresting incidents of her childhood and at the same time makes com parisons of Then and Now. In her own words, she tells this story When I was a baby, lying on the floor on a pillow, four Yankee sol diers came by our home. One of them asked my mother how old I was and she told them. Then he ask ed my name and my mother proud ly told him, Emma Lee, named for the General. The soldier c-ursed-and said they killed all babies named after Lee. At that time my Aunt Lou rushed in from the kitchen and said my name was Emma Leeola, which quick thinking on her part saved my life. Mrs. Woodson proudly tells that her late father, First Sgt. Jones, was ordered by General Robert E. Lee to stand up on the buggy and call out and tell the soldiers I have surrendered. She said My father was an un dertaker. While he was delivering a coffin one afternoon, a customer came in and wanted a coffin. I ask ed if he brought the measurements with him and he said he did. I cut the lumber by the measurements, made the coffin and Stained it, made the delivery and collected the 3.00 before my father returned. Mrs. Woodson recalls traveling from Prince Edward County to Ap pomattox in a wagon with her fam ily to witness the Dedication of the New Court House here. She is the mother of three chil dren and one adopted son. Now liv ing is her son in Florida and her adopted son, Leroy Woodson, of Bal timore. Md. Her late husband was a carpenter and he could raise a house as good as anybody, said Mrs. Woodson. For a number of years, Mrs. Woodson was a practical nurse, hav ing nursed in every hospital in Rich mond. When asked how many times she has been a patient in a hospital,

document.text: Mrs. Mattie Walton Purdum, 89, died April 6 in Front Royal, during a visit with her daughter, Mrs. Har old Stossell. She had been ill for ten days. She was born in Appomattox County, the daughter of the late Thomas A. and Martha Woodson Walton. She was the widow of Edward E. Purdum, and the second oldest member of Liberty Baptist Church. Her body will rest at the church from 1230 until 230 P. M. Thurs day. Graveside services will be con ducted at 300 P. M. Thursday by Dr. Carl A. Collins, Jr., at Liberty Baptist Church Cemetery. Besides her daughter, she is sur vived by four sons, Dr. E. A. Pur- dum, of Hot Springs, Ark. C. W. Purdum, of Niles, Ohio Dr. R. B. Purdum, of Elkins, W. Va.,-and Ru fus Purdum, of Front Royal and three sisters, Mrs. Annie Staples, of Concord Mrs. Ella Jamerson and Mrs. Carrie Moses, both of Appo mattox.

document.text: With the Vice President Dr. Merwyn Williamson presiding in the absence of the President, Mr. Gilbert Lusk, the Appomat tox County Historical Society held its regular October meeting recently. The resignation of the President, due to a transfer of professional duties to Gettys burg National Park was accepted with regrets. Highlight of the October meeting focused on a seven hundred dollar donatimi for historical research from the Woodmen of the W orld, donation of 1914 news articles and other documents concern ing the late Congressman Henry D. Flood, and the Birth Pangs of Appomattox County depicted in a talk by Mr. Ron Wilson. Mrs. Harry Clark Rucker presented the Flood news articles to the Glory of God and to the members of the society. To her the beauty of any possession is dependent on  the degree to which it is shared i with others. Amy possession to predoifl to share is not worth  having. The thing then becomes j the master of the man. Mrs. Rucker, the former j Helen Nowlin, the great-grand-1 daughter of Lawyer John Woodson whose office is one of ! the restored buildings at J Appomattox National Park, is i the daughter of the late Annie ! Thornhill and Albert Sidney ! Nowlin. Her mother, from the I Hollywood area of the county, and her father, from the! Oakville area, are widely j related throughout the county. The firuest speaker for the evening, Ron Wilson, Historian at Appomattox Court House Rational Historic Park, spoke on th e Birth Pangs of Appomattox County,1845 - 1870. The speech, based on research, one by Dr.  John Moore, Research H istorian, University of Virginia, depicted the February 8,1845 birthing of Appomattox County from the parent counties of Buckingham, Campbell, Prince Edward and

document.text: William Edward Dickerson, 93, of Spout Spring, died Tues day at his hom e. He was the husband of the late Nannie Mor ris Dickerson. Born in Appomattox County, he was a son of Elijah Thomas Dickerson and Sallie Woodson Dickerson. He was a member of Salem United Methodist Church. He was a merchant in Spout Spring for 55 years. He is survived by three sons, Claude M. Dickerson of Spout Spring, Earl H. Dickerson of Lynchburg and W. E. Dickerson Jr. of Chatham six daughters, Mrs. H. B. document.text: The new school at Oakville held ta first commencement exeroiaes on the 3rd, 4tb and 5th of April. The bonse was crowded to overflowing and mnoh enthusiasm was shown by the patrons as well as the pnpils. On Sunday night the 3rd, Rev. H. T. Allison preached a most ex cellent edncational sermon whioh was enjoyed by all present. On Monday night the small chil dren entertained the crowd with recitations, songs, drills and panto mimes. Master Dnrnard Thomas antomimed Old Black Joe, and also reeited A Burlesque on Wom ans Rights, whiebbrought down the house. Dnrnard is a talented boy and imitated a  darkey so well that some of the visitors really thonght he belonged to that race. After the exroisea Mr. R. F. Burke made a most interesting address on schools and the importance of ed ucation. He also presented the prises to the pnpils of the primary room. May. Harvey received the prize on spelling, Cornelia. Woodson, writing, Hettie Woodson, reading and Alex Btarria, arithmetic. On Tuesday night the grammar and high school department held 8way. The exeroise opened with America, whioh was snag and pantomimed by the school. Mr. James Lueado made the salutatory address which was enjoyed by all. James is a cool-headed speaker and haa talent that ie worth cultivating. Again, we had recitations, drill, marches, dialogues, pantomiems and tableanx. Special mention ahonld be made of Mr. William Albert Owen w h o declaimed Patrick Henrys famous speech end wcaclao valedictorian. He poaesses rare oratorical powers and held the au dience spellbound. At the beginning ot the session Hon. A. F. Thomas gave 10.00 with whioh to bay books as prises for the students. Midi Myrtle Thomas received the prises on geography and physiology, Miss Ethel Marsh on reading and com position, Miss Mary Harris, on grammar and arithmetic, Miss Go- lena Martin, composition, Mr. Tom Owen and Miss Myrtle Thomas tied tor the history prise, so it was divided between them. Mi sea Lois Lueado and Mary Harris each re ceived a prize on writing and Mr. William Albert Owen received the debaters prise. The scholarship mfcdal offered by Messrs. Ferguson, Owen and Thomas, was awarded to Miss Mary Harris. Prof. J. G. Fisher, of Stonewall High School delivered the medal. The music rendered by Messers. Edward and Lndwell Childress, on the violin and banjo added mnoh to the occasion These musicians are both talented and accomodating. The exercises closed with  Oakville High School, one of the school songs. The school made rapid progrrss daring the short time it was in ses sion only three months end thir teen days. Mnch credit is dne to the Principal Mias Frances Moss, and her sister Miss Mattie, in tbe training of these pupils. May this school grow better year by year and in time become one of the best in the State.

Haywood Robinson, pastor of the church, officiated at the double ring ceremony. A program of nuptial music was presented by Mr. Hiawa tha Johnson and Mr. Timo- theues Lawing. Examinations for the white teach ers for the white schools of Appo mattox opened Angnst 15th, 1893, with the following applicants pres ent Misses Rosalie Wheeler, Judith W. Coleman, Grace L. Watts, Sallie M. Bnrke, Maggie S. Smith, Cora Blox- ton, Eunice S. Cheadle, Bertha Wool dridge, Sallie E. Bice, Evie F. Conch, Pattie F. Womack, Onie S. Jennings, Myrta M. Woodson, Sallie Dawson, Lula V. Dawson, Addie Dawson, Mattie S. Moss, Alpha A. Feather ston, Juddie E. Coleman, Helen L. Abbitt, Maggie V. Chilton, Anna B. Moss, Mattie A. Coleman, Lucy C. Thornhill, Maggie Thornhill, Etta Bloxton. Messrs. C. F. Morton, H. 9. B. Martin, F. W. Swan, Fred C. Hunt. Miss Bose -Womack, of Prince Edward, a full graduate of the State Female Normal School at Farmville, Va., presented her diploma and signed the teachers blank. She is preparing to submit an application for a school. The number of applicants present promises ns a sufficiency of teachqfs. An expert, while looking on, re marked that the schools of Appo mattox must be on the upward march for those in attendance evinced much intelligence and a remarkable im provement, and that their appearance was splendid. Our representative can most heartily echo these words of praise. Mr. Chap. Chiltou deserves to be highly commended for-the careful discipline he exercises over these ex aminations. He is evidently deter mined that they shall be a fair and honest test, and every one should ac cord him a well-merited approbation.

document.text: Substantial decreases were shown by King and Queen 14-1, Prince Edward 11-1, Alleghany 11-2, and Spotsylvania 20-9. On the other hand, deaths rose considerably in Hanover 15-29 and Dinwiddle 7-16. Both Elizabeth City and Warkick entered the statue of cities during the year but each showed healthy reductions. For the cities, Richmond led with 26 deaths although Staunton, with three, had the worst rate based on deaths per 100,000 population. In the above-50,000 population group decreases were shown by Roanoke 9-71, Norfolk 23-16, and Rich mond 39-26, but increases occur red in Portsmouth 6-9 and Alex, andria 5-9, For the entire state, pedestrian deaths dropped from 251 to 201 . However, Col. Woodson pointed to the continuing and alarming rise in the deaths of servicemen which reached 127 during the year. This was a substantial increase over the 84 of 1951, Total accidents rose from 53,633 to 58,825 and 820 of these killed one or more persons each. Previous fatal accident score was 785. There were 25,218 people injured against 23,898 of the pre ceding year and economic and prop erty losses exceeded 90 million. For the year, traffic volumes were about 7 per cent higher than in 1951.

Mr. Johp Bingham and son Curtis, wno have both been confined to their beds with pneumonia, are getting along nicely now and we hope to see them out soon. Some of the hunters who have visited our neighborhood have had splendid success kill iog turkeys and birds Mr. Edward Ferguson seems to be quite hapoy helping to care for his wife and new little daughter. We want to ask for a chick en from every family that be longs to Herman church, to send to our Orphanage for Christmas. document.text: P in ey M ountain Team Out Strong. JVith fourteen men out for the team last Saturday the Mount aineers are anticipating the strongest team in the history of their base ball career. Not withstanding the fact that the diamond is a little rough tbe men had a light workout m the field and a stiff drill in the pol ling art, at which they seem to be up to their old standard. Len Ohilders the little Ap pomattox champion at receiv ing, will resume his old posi tion, and on him the team is counting for a part of her bat tery. Lud Childers will do the twirling un ill Chris Christian returns from Richmond college, when he will tae his place on the staff. And on the initial sack Leslie Gordon the left- hand star will perform, on sec ond there is the old veteran Harry Woodson and at short Jim Childers the fast little de mon will be the main stay at third Ira Lucado will be sta tioned. In the field there are Delbert Gordon, Edward Fergerson and Jim Luoado, and in the sub-line, Ed Childers, Kenneth Barlow and Little Lucado are doing good work. If the old men dont get a hustle on and play fast ball some of these so called rats will boost them out of a place on tbo varsity team As the manager of he team has not arranged any definate schedule the exact time of the first game is not known but will probably be staged at Oakville with the Oakville High School lads. The team regrets very much the loes of two valuable men, Jim Megginson catcher, who has signed up with Liberty Chapel High School and Elmo Wilkerson pitcher, who is un able to plav on aeoount of an injured leg.

This letter should have appeared the first week in August, hut was de layed in reaching this office.E d . THI DIBINO SOr.DniR IN CUB!. A eeldler l-i y dielng In Cuba, Hia life blood was fast ebbing aw ay And bis cheeks were flushed and fallen, That told his death was to-day. As he lay on the battle field. He thought of the happy days gone by When a school hoy in America, The happy land of the brave and free. And as his thoughts still wandered. He thought of the heart th at was beating For th at brave young soldier boy. That died in the battle to day. He thought of his sweetheart. When they vowed theyed be true. But now they are never to meet Until Gods Judgm ent Day. Faintly the words he whispers To others standing around. Tell m other and sweetheart I love them But never shall I see them again. One more look at Old Glory, The soldier raises his ej es. And gaze a t the battle flag That represents the country he adores. The clock ticks his last second. The soldier closes his eyes And one more name is w ritten. On the death roll to-day. X.

Williamson and children, Skippy, Rhonda and Joe arrived Friday A. M. to spend the month of August with his par ents, Mr. and Mrs. W. L. William son. They have been in Austin Texas for the past year, where Mr Williamson has been working on his Ph. D. degree in English at the University of Texas. During the last week in August, Mr. and Mrs. Will iamson will go to Camp Miniwanca Michigan, for a Danforth Founda tion Conference on Christianity and Higher Education. Mr. Williamson has received a Danforth Foundation Teacher Grant for his studies in 1955-56.

document.text: Industry and activity are adjectives applicable to Hazel Harvey and the Bicentennial year is her forte. The orginator of the Appo mattox historical doll collection Mrs. Harvey has just returned from a trip in Virginia, West Virginia, Maryland and North Carolina, where she exhibited her dolls and spoke to various groups. A native of Covington she lives in a historic house at Vera, where she and the late Thomas Harvey, her husband, raised their family in an early 18th century house which was once a stage stop. Her! book, Bicentennial U. S.A., Historical Dolls and Sketches by Hazel Harvey is a salute to Peacetown, Appo mattox. In her Acknowledgement she states This booklet is a tribute to Elvira W oodson Harvey 1838-1927 from whom the local stories and pictures were obtained. The facts can be substantiat ed by the History of New Hope Baptist Church, Appomattox, Virginia, records in Appomat tox, Frince Edward and Buckingham counties... Appomattox played a great part in. uniting our nation in 1865. The local people and events are duly recognized here. As we commemorate the Bicentennial of our nation 1976 Let Us Salute Peacetown, USA. document.text: Concord News. A joint convention of the Peoples party of Appomattox and Campbell counties met in Evans Hall, this place, at noon last Friday to nominate a floater to the legislature, from the above named counties. Chas. T. Moses, of Appomattox,, was chosen chairman, and Dr. T. W. Evans, of Campbell, secretary of the conven tion. Wm. A. Thornhill, of Appo mattox, was nominated by acclama tion- as the floater candidate. There were about thirty delegates in attendance and considerable enthus iasm prevailed in their ranks. Ed ward Moormaw, Dr. T. W. Evans, C. B. Bloxton, Jas. P. Fleshman and others responded to calls for speeches. Each speaker seemed to he quite sanguine of the success of their ticket, and well pleased with the general outlook for their party in the State. A very ludicrous, if not significant, incident occurred while the conven tion was in session. A large flock of scavenger birds, commonly known as tnrkey buzzards, after hovering for a while over the Convention Hall took flight in direction of Charlotte county. It was a custom amongst the ancient augurs to predict success or failure of any enterprise from the flight of birds and it may be that onr Third party brethem can gather some consolation from this question able omen. However, a local wit comments on the incident in this manner These birds were in hot pursuit of the defunct remains of the Third party, and after locating it in the Convention Hall, immedi ately took flignt to Charlotte, where it had been previously announced, that there would be a similar gather ing of the same party on Monday. Rev. J. W. Hilldrup has been con ducting protracted services at Salem church, during the past week. Seven persons united themselves with Bethlehem church at this place on last Sabbath, as a result of a series of meetings held with the above-men tioned church, and conducted by Rev. Mr. Hilldrup, assisted by Rev. L. B. Betty, of Court street church, Lynchburg. Rev. Wm. Fisher returned from Clays Crossing last Friday, where he had been assisting his son, Dr. W. F. Fisher, in a series Of meetings. Miss Coston, of Salisburg, N. C., has accepted a situation as teacher, in the family of Mr. Jos. Cardwell, for the next session. Miss E. P. Abbott, a recent gradu ate of the Methodist Female college, Danville, Va., will teach a select school at her home, Edgewood, dur ing the fall and winter. - j Prof. Ruse Evans, formerly of this place, has been elected assistant instructor in New London Academy, Bedford connty. Mr. Osman Howerton, who has been quite ill with fever, is now con valescent. Mr. James Akers has recovered sufficiently from his recent attack of rheumatism, as to appear in town again Saturday. Jim may have been low in spirit, bnt he holds on to the avoirdupois just the same.. Mrs. Victoria Arrington, in com pany with her daughters, Misses Sallie and Florie,is visiting her sister, Mrs. Woodson, in Lynchburg. Misses Annie and Della Steele, of this place, will leave for Roanoke, Wednesday the 15th inst. Miss L. B. Pan key, of Pamplin City, is visiting Mrs. Dr. Mott Rob ertson, near Spout Springs. Misses Taylor and Bondurant, stu dents in the South Side Female Insti tute, left for Burkeville, Wednesday. Dr. Edward D. Fisher, of Durham, N. C., reached here Monday morning on a visit to his old home. Your paper is extremely popular in our place, and we wish you all success iu your worthy enterprise. Q uid nunc ? Sept. 11, 1893.

document.text: By MARY BAGBY Come unto me, all ye that labor and are heavy laden, and I will give  you rest. Take my yoke upon you, and learn of me, for I am meek and lowly in heart, and ye shall find rest unto vour souls. For my yoke is easy and my burden is light Matt 1128-30 Our hearts were deeply saddened when word came Monday of the tragic death of Staff Set. Ben H. Maxwell who was killed in a terrorist attack in Beirut, Lebanon. He was a native of Appomattox and a member of Hollywood Baptist Church. Ben was liked and loved by all that he came in contact with. Our deep and heartfelt sympathy is extended his mother, Mrs. Virginia Maxwell, his wife, Sirs. Maxine Maxwell, five sisters, Barbara, Nancy, Lelia, Janie and Martha and other- loved ones and friends. We wish to extend our sincere sympathy to Rev. and Mrs. W. H. Elder and family in the death of his mother, Mrs. Cary Elder of Halifax who passed away at the Virginia Baptist Hospital Thursday. Our prayers and love are with her family and loved ones. Chucky Daniel, the infant son of Mr. and Mrs. Wayne Moss of Dfilwyn, died suddenly Friday. Mrs. Moss is the former Jane Ferguson and a daughter of Mr. Nat Ferguson. We extend our sincere sympathy and prayers to the family and loved ones.  We are so glad Mr. Henry Earl Covington, who is still a patient at the University Hospital at Char lottesville, is improving somewhat. We wish him a speedy recovery. Mr. Ernest L. Day is still a patient in the Lynchburg General Hospital, but we are happy to hear he is improving. We wish him a speedy recovery. We hope Mr. John Goin, who isnt to well at this time, may soon be well again. We are very sorry to hear Miss Donna Franklin fell Saturday night and broke her leg in two places. Our prayers are with her. May she have a speedy recovery. We hope Mrs. Elmo Smith may be feeling better real soon. Mr. Lewis Harris remains ill in the University Hospital at Char-  lottesville. Our prayers are with him and his love ones. Among those visiting Mr. and Mrs. Robert Coleman were Mr. Calvin Smith and Mr. and Mrs. Allen Carmody. document.text: Almost insane from jealousy, Capt, Edward W. Jones, commanding Com pany E , of the Seventy-first Regiment, prominent-in politics and business cir cles in Norfolk,-killed Maude Cameron, and then slashed his own throat at the the womans house. She went to Nor folk about a year ago, after graduation from a convent in Carolina. She met Jones, who became infatuated with her, and she returned his affection. Each, it is said, were intensely jealous of the other, and this jealousy caused the trag edy. Mr. John Johnson, an aged and re spected farmer of the Fork district, Warren county, was attacked on Main street, near Johnson Bros. confectionery store, by Janies E. Conner and cut in the neck, cheek and stomach, making three very serious wounds. Mr. John son was also hit across the head-by Ben jamin Sonner with a heavy club, which rendered his unconscious for a long time. There seems to have been a long-stand ing grudge between Johnson and Son ner. Johnson is being attended by Dr. M. L. Garrison. Both James E. Sonner and his son Benjamin were arrested. Mr. Johnsons condition is serious. Dorsey Mills, a young white man, aged about 23 , had his left foot crushed between the bumpers of two freight cars of a Southern Railway freight at Front Royal. Mills, it seems, attempted to cross the bumper, when the train gave a sudden lurch and caught his foot. Dr. Kipps was immediately upon the scene to render medical assistance. Amputa tion may be necessary. The cutting of the channel of the Ap pomattox River from Petersburg to James River, at City Point, to a depth of 12 feet and width of 40 feet, was completed Friday. The work was done by the United States Government, at a cost of  10 , 000 . The government will begin work immediately on the diversion of the Appomattox River, the cost of which will be  150 , 000 , to be paid for by the government. One man was killed and five others hurt by the bursting of a 28 -foot fly wheel in the bar mill of the Tredegar Iron Works, Richmond. The shed in which it was situated was wrecked, and the wheel, broken into several large pieces, flew in every direction, parts of it landing over on Gambles Hill Park, across the canal. The Old Virginia Copper Company, owned by Pittsburg and Indiana capi talists, has just been organized in Lu- ray. The company is to develop the mineral lands near Stony Man Camp, seven miles east of Luray. The home office is to be in Fort Wayne, Ind. The copper deposits at this place are said to be among the richest in the State. The police of Winchester are scouring the city and surrounding country for a young white man, supposed to be J. C. Rainey, of Jefferson county, West Vir ginia, who went by the name of M. C. Morgan, who is wanted for passing al leged worthless checks on Winchester merchants. The Henrico County Jail, built a few years ago, is about to collapse. Big cracks have occurred in the walls on account of the ground sinking. No pris oners are being kept in that part of the building because of the danger. A big sewer running under the jail is the probable cause of the trouble. In Lynchburg owners of all places of public resort, factories and boarding houses three stories or more in height have been notified that they must com ply with a new city ordinance which re quires the erection of iron fire-escapes. Mr. Gus Rock, a prominent farmer and citizen of Farnaham, was run over by a two-horse wagon loaded with to matoes. The wheel passed over his body, inflicting injuries from which he died. Thomas Parsons, colored, shot and killed Thomas Banks, another negro, at Rideway Church, in Buckingham, during a protracted meeting. Parsons claims self-defense, saying Banks hit him with his fist. Banks .is a bad name among the negroes of Buckingham, two of the name having committed atrocious mur ders recently. The annual convention of the Womans Christian Temperance Union of Win chester and Frederick county was held at Winchester in the Market Street Methodist Episcopal Church. Mrs. Amy Weech, State superintendent of evan gelistic work, responded to the address of welcome of Mrs. Arthur Leaf. Miss Lona A. Kerns, of Winchester, was elected president Miss Lizzie Arnold, of Stephen City, corresponding secretary Mrs. C. H. Buchanan, of Brucetown, re cording secretary, and Mrs. John Locke, of Stephen City, treasurer. Miss Lucy Anderton, of Tappahan- nock, on the Rappahannock River, and her guests had a narrow escape from drowning while sailing. In the boat were Miss Dorothy Hope and Mr. May, of Baltimore, and Mr. Henry Temple. The boat capsized in the channel and the occupants clung to it until rescued after a terrible experience by two negroes. Genevie Scott, the little son of Robert Scott, of Pocahontas, a suburb of Peters burg, attempted to jump on a freight train on the Norfolk and Western Rail road while passing through Blandford. He fell and had his right leg and arm so badly crushed that he died at the Home for the Sick. H. J. Fraley, a well-known citizen of Rappahannock county, is dead at his home near Sperryville, 14 miles east of Luray. His death was due to typhoid fever. Several other members of his family have the fever. Gideon Hoake, one of the oldest citi zens of Page county, died at his home near Ida, eight miles south of Luray. He was about 85 years of age and is survived by seven children. Mr. John H. Harrison, of Petersburg, and Mrs. Sallie Cordle, of Brunswick county, his sister, met in Petersburg for the first time in 20 years. Mrs. Cordle has been the mother of 10 children and the grandmother of 64 grandchildren. Nine of the former and 40 of the latter are now living, and she has three great grandchildren alive. Judge John D. Horsley fell down the steps at the Academy of Music, Lynch burg, in trying to save an old gentleman who had fallen. The Judge fractured his cheekbone. The incident probably will cause him to postpone a trip to Europe, which he was about to begin. I Magistrate Angle, of Henrico county, passed the death sentence on a dog train ed by three negro boys to steal .chickens and bring them to his masters. Many depredations have occurred by the use of this dog. The three negroesPercy Bundy, Charles Woodson and Benja min Joneswere sentenced for chicken I stealing. There was a head-on collision on the Norfolk and Western railroad at Suth erlands Station, Dinwiddle county, be tween a loaded easibound coal train and I an empty train going west. Both loco motives were badly damaged and five I cars wrecked.

document.text: are almost swallowed up with grass. There is an abundance of apples, and almost every one is making cider. Peaches are a failure, so much wet weather caused them to decay and drop off before they were ripe. Messrs. Lewis and Woodsons new th-esher was in the neighborhood the past week. The wheat crop generally is not as good as wa-j ex pected, Mrs. J. W. North, of Ljnch! urg, was visiting Mrs. J. E. Coleman the past week. Mrs. Coleman has moved into her beautiful new home. We extend a warm welcome to her and her interesting family, and are glad to see this new home built up in the Southside. Prof, Anderson Fitzgerald, of Huntington, W. Va., was the guest of his aunt, Mrs. G. A. Coleman, recently. Miss Joe Warren, of Pamplin, spent last week with Misses Bernice and Landon Cole. Mr. Mayuard Fowlkes, of Luhen.- burg O. H., is summering with his grandparents here. Messrs. S. P. Coleman and T. N. Oder went to Richmond recently to see Mr. Ellis Oder, who was criti callv ill with typhoid fever. Tlii 3 is the third time that Mr. Oder has had this dread disease. Mr. S. F. Calhoun, an old Appo mattox boy, now the efficient ageiri of the N.  W. at Bel Spring, visit ed relatives at Mountain View Fri day and Saturday. He has been en joying a weeks outing at Pinev Beach, and is very enthusiastic in his praise of that new resort. Dave Plunkett, son of Mr. J. S Plunkett, had a bad fall from a horse cue day last week. He has his arm in a iling and we under stand one of the bones was broken. News was received here of the death at her faUieis home in Gra bam of little Mary Judson, th twelve-months-old baby of Mr. ano Mrs. Jos. W. Coleman. The littn body was brought to Lynchburg and laid to rest in beautiful Spring Hill cemetery. Two little grave guarded by the augels, two litil lambs safely housed in the Gooe Shepherds fold. Be comforted be reaved parents, they are not, lost only gone before. Mr. T. W. Oder was in the Ilil! City with tobacco on Thuisday. Miss Sadie Coleman expects t leave on Friday next for an extend ed visit to friends at Hurtsville and relatives in Prince Edward and Buckingham. Mr. John T. Cole is visiting his father, who is quite feeble iu Pitt sylvania. Thera will be a ministers and deacons meeting at Promise Land church colored on Saturday and Sunday i.ext. There is a good Sab bath School at this chnrch, and prayer meeting every Sunday even ing. Miss Elvyn Coleman has a patch of the finest tobacco we have ever seen this early. Some of the plants are almost as large as she is. The political pot has ceased to hoii in this section, or is it that it has not commenced, and candidates are conspicuous by their absence. Oh, yes. Mr. Editor, we see the waste basket but please allow us a little more space iu which o assure your Charlotte correspondent that we are Tery much awake, and wish she would rouse Carliue. It has been quite a lou  time since we heaid from her, and Lv.cinday wonders if hey are both married.
